Award.AwardTitle: From Micelles to Membranes: Advanced Block Polymer Ionic Liquid Composites
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The goal of this project is to advance a new class of functional nanostructured materials by combining ionic liquids with block copolymers. Ionic liquids exhibit many appealing properties, including chemical and thermal stability, vanishing vapor pressure, tunable solvation, high ionic conductivity, and high dielectric constant, that render them appealing as potential 'green' solvents, and as key ingredients in plastic electronics, batteries, fuel cells, gas separation membranes, and actuators. To realize these properties in advanced materials applications, it is necessary to solidify the material, and/or to confine the ionic liquid within a desired nanostructure. Block copolymers offer unprecedented flexibility to direct self-assembly over lengthscales from 1-100 nanometers, while simultaneously providing mechanical integrity. Three different sub-projects are envisioned that address fundamental issues in polymer materials science, and each exploits a unique aspect of nanostructured copolymer/ionic liquid mixtures. First, a quantitative understanding of the rate of chain exchange in block copolymer micelles will be established, by utilizing time-resolved small-angle neutron scattering on isotopically labeled micelle mixtures. By virtue of the wide usable temperature range of ionic liquids, and the ease with which critical micellization temperatures can be tuned predictably by blending homologous imidazolium cations, the crossover from 'ergodicity' to 'non-ergodicity' will be delineated systematically. Second, the recent discovery of ionic-liquid-filled vesicles dispersed in water will be extended to nanoreactor applications, whereby the catalyst is confined to the vesicle interior, and may be recovered easily. The aqueous matrix mitigates the severe cost and mass transfer restrictions of ionic liquid reaction media, while the vesicle membrane will regulate the rate of reactant and product partitioning between aqueous and ionic liquid phases. Last, an ABC triblock terpolymer approach is proposed to prepare crosslinked bi- and tri-continuous membranes with conductive, ionic-liquid-rich nanochannels, with the goal of accessing unprecedented combinations of high mechanical toughness and ionic conductivity.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Composite materials prepared from polymers and room temperature ionic liquids are under active consideration for many advanced technologies, including biomass modification, gas separation membranes, plastic electronics, ion batteries, and fuel cells. Success in any of these areas would have profound societal impact in terms of energy conservation, sustainable plastics, and portable energy storage. Simultaneous optimization of diverse properties, such as high ionic transport, mechanical integrity, and facile processing, can best be achieved through structural control at the nanometer scale. Thus, the combination of structure-directing block copolymers and functional ionic liquids will accelerate the development of advanced materials. Graduate students will acquire a broad suite of skills in polymer synthesis and characterization, light, x-ray and neutron scattering, fluorescence spectroscopy, and electron microscopy. They will also have extensive opportunities to present technical talks and posters to external audiences, as well as to mentor talented undergraduates in research. High school students from the greater Twin Cities, particularly women and underrepresented minorities, will be exposed to polymer science through "Polymer Day: You Make It, You Break It", a hands-on component of a broader "Exploring Careers in Science & Engineering" summer camp.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes: DMR-1206459

This research project was aimed at combining the ability of block polymers to impart structure and mechanical strength, with the appealing physical and chemical properties of a promising class of green solvents called ionic liquids. Block polymers are macromolecules that combine two or more chemically distinct blocks that prefer not to mix. The consequence is that these materials spontaneously undergo self-assembly, to produce a rich variety of nanostructured materials. Ionic liquids, or molten salts, are of great interest for their chemical and thermal stability, their high ionic conductivity, and their complete non-volatility. This project included studies directed at systems dilute in polymers, such as micelles and gels, with a view towards ultimate applications in synthesis and extraction, and also more concentrated, ordered systems with greater mechanical integrity, with potential use in fuel cells, batteries, and optical switches.

            We designed block polymer vesicles – bilayer membranes akin to cells – that contained ionic liquid plus catalyst, yet were dispersed in water. Such nanoreactors combine the benefits of homogenous and heterogeneous catalysis, while overcoming the mass transfer limitations of typically viscous ionic liquids. The vesicle size could be well controlled, and the rates of entry and escape for various probe molecules were quantified as a function of vesicle size, membrane thickness, and polymer identity. A more fundamental study explored the self-assembly of block polymers in ionic liquids in terms of their ability to find the equilibrium structure, as opposed to becoming trapped in a metastable state. Using the advanced technique of small-angle neutron scattering, the rate at which individual molecules leave and re-enter individual micelles was quantified. Interestingly, the results are in conflict with the best available theory, suggesting the need for further investigation.

            We have pioneered the design, preparation, and application of ion gels, soft solids containing an ABA copolymer network. Such physical gels have many desirable attributes, including thermoreversibility when the A block can be rendered soluble by changing temperature. This allows processing in the liquid state, followed by solidification in situ. We extended this concept to chemical gels, whereby the A blocks could be chemically crosslinked after self-assembly, either by application of light or heat, thereby allowing spatial patterning and providing much greater toughness. Photoreversible ion gels were also achieved, by incorporating a small fraction of photochromic units into the A block. Depending on the color of light used to illuminate the sample, the gel would melt or reform, as the photochromic moieties have different solubility in the ionic liquid. A further route to enhanced ion gels used ABC triblocks, where the differing thermo- or photosensitivity of the A and C blocks enables multiple processing routes and stimulus responsiveness.

            Polymer-based, specific-ion-conducting membranes with high mechanical and thermal integrity are of interest for diverse applications including ion batteries and fuel cells. A central challenge is to simultaneously optimize orthogonal properties such as conductivity and modulus. A kinetic, polymerization-induced microphase separation strategy is an appealingly simple one-pot approach, in which all ingredients are mixed together and allowed to react. This yielded a robust nanostructured polymer membrane exhibiting a record combination of modulus and ionic conductivity. This concept was further extended to both proton and lithium-ion conducting membranes. It is also of interest to explore whether an equilibrium strategy can produce similarly co-continuous, ionically-conducting materials. Indeed, a judicious mixture of three components – an A polymer, a B polymer, and an AB diblock – can spontaneously assemble into a bicontinuous microemulsion. We showed that this delicate state of matter can also be prepared in the presence of added ionic liquids, an exciting new development; interesitngly, the ionic conductivity that showed unanticipated variations with material morphology.
